March 7, 1901.

No. 10

OUR TWENTY-FIFTH ANNIVERSARY. student body; frequent interruptions and
several reasons the Commemoration Day
FOR
Celebration in McCoy Hall, on February
was the grandest and most impressive of
many years past. It not only marked the
twenty-fifth birth-day of the University, but
witnessed, with regrets, the resignation of the
first and only president of the institution.
The attention of the public, which has been
recently turned upon Johns Hopkins on account of our newly acquired possessions, also
contributed to gather the illustrious assemblage which makes the day a memorable one.
The one thing, however, which remained to
distinguish the day in the annals of the University, and to mark the beginning of a new
epoch of unprecedented success, was wanting.
Students, faculty, and friends alike waited with
hopeful expectation to hear the announcements
from "Uncle Dan," but the all important one,
the one which all had 'anxiously awaited,
brought only disappointment. Let us all,
like Uncle Dan, "have faith in the people,
faith in human nature."
Another subject for surmise among the
audience was the probable successor of President Gilman. One or two newspapers have
insinuated that Dr. David J. Hill, the orator
of the day, may be the man, but thus far,
nothing definite has been learned. The ovation given Dr. Hill at the conclusion of his
speech, by friends and students alike, plainly
attests the favorable impression which he
made. His address was both eloquent and
scholarly, and his personality plainly indicates
those qualities which always command respect.
The yelling in one or two instances was very
ill-timed. "There is a time for all things,"
and upon these occasions extraordinary care
should be taken in the control of such demonstrations. Appropriate yells at seasonable
moments not only lend interest to the programme, but impress the audience very favorably with the college spirit and unity of the
22,

ragged yelling at untimely moments, however,
become extremely annoying, and brand the
students as rowdies, having very indistinct
ideas of propriety. One or two outbreaks of
this nature were visible on Commemoration
Day, and in the future pains should be taken
to eliminate such detrimental proceedings.
An assemblage of well-known statesmen and
scholars filled the stage. Besides our able
faculty were a number of distinguished guests,
including Senor Aspirez, the Mexican ambassador; Mr. Torey, of the Mexican embassy;
Count and Countess Lichtervelde, the minister
from Switzerland, and many others, among
them our kind benefactors, Mr. William Wyman and Mr. William S. Keyser.
Following the chant "Benedictus," President Gilman introduced Dr. Hill, who gave a
highly entertaining address on "The Influence
of Universities upon National Life."
The degree of Doctor of Philosophy was
conferred upon Messrs. George Ernest Barnett,
Benjamin Palmer Caldwell, Arthur Henry
Ewing and Norman Everett Gilbert.
President Gilman announced his resignation
in a simple, brief address, and proceeded to
the announcements. In a few words the expectant audience was informed that the $1,000,000 had not yet made its appearance, and that
no means for securing it had yet been devised.
No little pleasure was expressed by the
friends of Dr. Paul Haupt at the honor conferred upon him by Emperor William. At
the conclusion of the exercises President and
Mrs. Gilman entertained Dr. Hill and the
guests from Washington in the Donovan Room.
During the day Dr. Gilman was the recipient of the following telegrams from the various

THE ALUMNI BANQUET.
IT felt quite like old times to meet the fellows
again, some of whom you had not seenfor a
year, some for two years, and sonic not since
you left the University. The hundred or more
of us who met at the Rennert the evening of
Commemoration Day did most heartily celebrate the twenty-fifth birthday of our Alma
Mater, and our reunion.
We were very fortunate to have with us that
evening Mr. Wyman,through whose generosity
Greater Johns Hopkins becomes a probability,
and although Messrs Keyser, and Jencks and
the other gentlemen who joined them in their
gift to us were not present, they were not
forgotten.
Mr. Geo. Dobbin Penniman was toastmaster,
and seated on either side of him at the head

table were the speakers of the evening, President Oilman, Messrs John K. Cowen, Wm.
H. Buckter, and Dr. James C. Mackenzie, of
Tome Institute, and Mr. J. R. Brackett, the
newly elected President of the Alumni Association.
Dr. Gilman was given quite an ovation of
cheers and applause when he entered the room,
and but for his especial request should like to
tell you all he said, but I can only hint that he
told us how he captured Drs. Gildersleeve,
Sylvester, and Rowland twenty-five years ago.
Dr. Gilman was followed by Mr. Wyman
who spoke a few words of thanks for the
hearty and prolonged applause which greeted
him. Then came Mr. Cowen who told us
what a good railroad man a college man made,
and also said, in reference to the proposed new
ballot, that he recommended its being printed
in Sanskrit so that only Dr. Haupt and a few
others as deeply versed in original and research
work might.have the honor of voting intelligently.
Dr. Mackenzie then gave us an interesting
account of the Prep. Schools which he called
the "Kitchens of the Universities."
The last speaker was Mr. Buckter who spoke
on the educated man, what he had done in the
past, and what was before him for the future.
In the intervals between toasts a quartette
from the Glee Club, and four members of .the
Banjo Club entertained us with music, and we
all sang some of the old songs we used to sing
when we were freshmen.
The banquet closed with Auld Sang Sync,
which was sung standing, and we all left to
meet again next year.
J. F. V. '98.

THE PUBLIC DEBATE.

JUNIOR BANQUET.

IT has been definitely decided that the Interclass Debate between Juniors and Seniors,
and the Freshman contest in public ipeaking,
will be held this year on Thursday, March
21st, at 8 p. in., in McCoy Hall. These contests always bring out interest in student
affairs by the public of Baltimore, and the
hall is generally filled to overflowing. This
year the debate, and the Freshman contest are
expected to be very interesting and exciting,
as the men of all three classes are working
hard. The side winning the debate receives
the Adams Trophy, which, despite the resignation of Prof. Adams, has again been offered,
and each member of the winning team is
recompensed by books also given by Dr.
Adams. The Lee Trophy is the reward to
the best Freshman Speaker.
The Senior team is hard at work with about
twelve candidates for the nine positions. The
men trying for the speakers' positions are :—
Bird, Boyer, Swindell, Tyler, Whitman, Riggins, Bandel, secretary, and Machen, chairman.
The members of the Junior team have also
been pushing along, and are making very
satisfactory progress. The first and second
speakers will be chosen shortly, and several
men have already begun training. Naughty
two is generally supporting the team, whose
meetings are weJ1 attended. The places will
probably be distributed among the following
men :—Markell, secretary, Diggs, Campbell,
Strouse, Stone, chairman, Neer, Pels, Putts,
Guggenheimer, Wohnan, Wroth. The question to be debated is Resolved, "That the
United States should build, own, operate and
control an inter-oceanic canal, by way of
Nicaragua." The Juniors have the affirmative,
and the Seniors the negative. The question
is a good one for debate, and a warm contest
may be expected.
'Four Freshmen will speak in the contest for
public speaking. Many men started out, but
at the time of going to press it was stated
that the speakers would probably be chosen
from the following :—Addison, Dochez, Blum,
Meeks, Tootle, Plaggemeyer, Zimmerman.

Junior Class held its annual banquet
THE
at the Mt. Vernon Hotel, on Thursday
evening, February twenty-first. The, affair
from start to finish was a success and everyone
enjoyed himself to his utmost. The presence
of Messrs Sneeringer and White was a sure
guarantee that there would be little time spent
in silent meditation, and the evening was one
grand opera. All the songs from the most
recent to those of "by gone days'' were sung,
and it was evident that there were other musical stars besides those on the Glee Club.
The menu and toast cards were tastefully
gotten up, and the committee on arrangements
Messrs.Beasley,Moore and Koppleman deserve
to be congratulated. The committee on toasts
was composed of Messrs Wroth, Sneeringer
and Myers. liben C. Hill was toastmaster,
and called upon the following men for toasts.
Robert E. Moore, "Old Toni Hopkins'';
Horace Gillespie, "Our Missing Ribs'' Lyman
C. Murphy, "Our Newly Acquired Possessions" ; Robert T. Crane, "Our Royal Selves";
W.J. Sneeringer, Jr., "Harmony In Uproar";
C. A. Myers,"Our Fincounter with the Freshman"; J. G. Campbell, "The Rough House
of Representatives'' -and Harvey B. Stone,
"Athletics." After the toasts, songs were
sung and stories were told till just before the
banquet broke up when everybody gathered
at one end of the hall and ended the evening
with "Rah! for the Black and Blue!" and
some rousing "Hullabaloo's."
It seems a pity that more of these banquets
could not be held throughout the year, for it is
the only chance that the men in the class have
to come together and know each other better.
Possibly later in the year, some "palm garden"
feeds can be held which will be just as jolly
and cost a great deal less.

With the exception of the "Hullabaloo,"
the NEWS-LETTER is the sole undergraduate
publication of the Johns Hopkins, and consequently occupies a unique position among
the college papers. Elsewhere it is usually
customary for a college paper to devote itself
exclusively to one particular line of work,—
humorous, literary, athletic, or to matters of
local interest, as the case may be, while we are
forced to cover the entire sphere. Hence, it
is our aim, first, to disseminate University
news, and second to publish such articles as
may be of interest to the reader. It is the
intention of the present board of editors to pursue this policy, and to aid us in this endeavor
we earnestly solicit the co-operation of every
Hopkins man, and particularly the undergraduates. Items of University interest, and helpful hints and suggestions would benefit us
materially. Above all, the NEWS-LETTER is.
conducted by the students, for the students.

our last issue a change has taken

place in the editorial staff of the NEws-

LETTER, and a new editor-in-chief, not without reluctance, assumes the arduous duties
connected with that office. Before proceeding
further it is eminently befitting to congratulate
the retiring editor upon the excellent manner
in which the paper has been conducted during
his incumbency in office. Mr. Norman Boyer
has been connected with the NEWS-LETTER
since his Freshman year, and has occupied
successively the positions of assistant athletic
editor, news editor, associate editor, and editor-in-chief. During the last-named period
Mr. Boyer's aim has been to exemplify in these
columns the province of the college paper,
namely, to publish that kind of news which
directly interests the student. In pursuing
this aim he has advanced the standard of the
paper, and, largely owing to his efforts, it now
occupies a much more vital position among
Hopkins students than it was possible for it to
hold a few years ago. The endeavor of the
the paper is to come in close contact with every
student of the University.

A vacancy now exists on the editorial staff
of the NEWS-LETTER, and an opportunity is
thereby afforded for a display of literary ability
among the aspiring members of the Freshman
Class. A position upon the NEWS-LETTER
gives a man good, practical experience in literary training, which will prove valuable to
him in after years, and we strongly urge those
who are desirous of obtaining this position to
hand in, as soon as possible, specimens of their
writing, in the form of accounts of athletic
events, or matters of University interest. The
vacancy will probably be filled before the next
issue of this paper, so the sooner the competitive articles are turned in the better.

THE NEWS-LETTER.
We wonder if the Board of Trustees knew
as much about this as does our smart New
England friend.
This logical conclusion rests upon the
statement made by President Gilman in the
course of the Commemoration Day exercises,
that next October a formal celebration of the
twenty-fifth anniversary of the beginning of
academic work is to be held, at which time
the retired President is expected to make a
few remarks, and the incoming executive will
make his inaugural address. This, says the
Massachusetts editor, does not look as if the
trustees were still groping in the dark.
Dr. David Jayne Hill, who delivered the
Commemoration Day address, would make an
admirable president, having already served in
that capacity at both Bucknell and Rochester
Universities. He is a man of culture and
learning, and is known extensively as an
author of works on finance, rhetoric, biography
and psychology.

the past week a subscription paper
DURING
for the improvement of our York Road
Athletic Grounds, has been circulated among
the students. The importance of signing this
subscription, whether the amount given be
large or small, cannot be underestimated,
for when the matter is sifted, it comes down to
the question of whether or not we wish to promote Hopkins athletics. Every one realizes
the inestimable service Physical Director Mackdermott rendered us by procuring, for a nominal sum, a five-year lease on the new American
League grounds; but while we have secured
the grounds, it requires a certain amount of
capital to make the necessary improvements,
and as the alumni are interested in the Homewood site, the money for our present needs
must come from the student body. The
"Homewood" athletic field will be a great
boon to us, when we get it, but in the meantime it is necessary to carry on athletics,
and while future Hopkins classes may enjoy
"Homewood," the present ones will use
American League Park.

PATIENCE.

LAST we have a dramatic club! This
ATannouncement
should bring joy into the
camp of Hopkins, and arouse the enthusiasm
of the mighty masses ready to support worthy
enterprises. The club has not only been organized, but a play has been chosen, the cast
selected, the chorus drilled, and the ballet
formed. Everything started smoothly, and it
is hoped that the impetus given to this undertaking by the student body will urge the organization to complete success this year and a permanent position among Hopkins institutions
in future decades. J. Alan Haughton, 1903,
conceived the idea, and he, with the men asked
to co-operate, pressed matters to a head with
admirable expediency, so that now it can be
announced that the opera, "Patience," by Gilbert and Sullivan, will be rendered by the
Hopkins "Puff and Patch Club," probably
during the last week in April.
Why should not Hopkins have a dramatic
society? Some years ago "The Mask and Wig
Club," of the University of Pennsylvania,
toured the country for two seasons with their
"Mr. and Mrs. Cleopatra," and "Miss Columbia," and were eminently successful. In 1893
or 1894 the "Triangle Club," of Princeton,
put forth "Julius Csar," a clever musical
burlesque; Chicago, in the spring of 1899, gave
"The Deceitful Dean," and now the students
of Columbia are producing at the Carnegie
Lyceum, in New York, "Princess Proud,"
written and composed entirely by the college
men. Hopkins ought to be able tc do every
bit as much in this line as the larger universities, and should exert every effort to produce
a successful play. The advantages to be derived from a dramatic club have already been
pointed out in these columns.
Almost everybody admits that the idea is
good if it can be worked out; and to show that
it is possible the "Puff and Patch Club" has
been started here in hopes that the students
will evince sufficient interest to earnestly take
hold of the matter, now in a tangible form.
The reasons why "Patience" has been selected
to air our histrionic abilities are obvious.
Whereas other good operas have been given

MANDOLIN CLUB.

Mandolin Club took part in an enterTHE
tainment given at the Girls' Latin School
last Thursday night. The Club was on the
programme to appear but twice, so that when
the last piece was played, there was nothing
else to do except to remain and wait for any
forthcoming refreshments, or to adjourn to the
street and there give the members of the Glee
Club a chance to air their voices.
Accordingly all the instruments were gathered together, and the crowd started down
Saint Paul Street singing "Bring the Wagon
Home, John." But on the way, some one,
evidently well acquainted with the situation of
the Woman's College Dormitories, suggested
that the men serenade the College girls. So
all turned back and started for the nearest
Home.
Here a number of popular songs and "Hullabaloos" were given, accompanied with sub-

dued applause from the upper windows. Then
things were thrown. Apples seemed to be the
greatest drug on the market, for during the
serenade many of these appeared. The men
at first were undecided how to take these
tokens, not knowing whether they were thrown
from love of the singing and the men, or from
a desire to discourage the serenaders. However, being a trifle vain, they decided it was
more complimentary than otherwise, for surely
College girls never waste apples when other
things would serve just as well as missiles.
So the concert continued till all the dormitories
had been visited and the night watchman not
appreciating the music (?) had brought a
policeman to his assistance. Then having no
permit to "give a performance on the street''
the crowd disbanded.

MR. FREDERICK HARRISON.
who will lecture here shortly,
MR.is Harrison,
of interest to students from two quite
distinct points of view. Besides holding high
rank as a critic and a master of English prose,
he is an important figure in the history of philosophic thought during the past half century.
A follower of Auguste Comte, whom he
expressly recognizes as his master, he many
years ago came into prominence as the prophet
of Positivism in England. While making
little if any addition to the doctrine itself, he
gave to its propaganda as a cult the powerful
aid of his literary ability. The "Religion of
Humanity'' had in him its ablest advocate.
His position with regard to Positivism was
closely akin to that held by Mr. Huxley toward the doctrine of evolution. They were
the defenders and expounders of their respective causes. To them the popular ear was
open. In the ferment attending the birth of
the theory of evolution, there was necessarily
much re-examination of philosophy, and it was
at this time that Mr. Harrison came to be
regarded as the especial champion of the Positivist cause in England. In recent years his
work has been along more purely literary lines,
although it is not improbable his philosophy
has had much to do with giving his work in
part a historical direction. To this we owe
his excellent study of "Oliver Cromwell''
and his suggestive book on the "Meaning of
History."

What is a dime of 1873 worth at present?
' —Collector.

The coin referred to is worth two sections of
pie in the lunch-room ; or half a hair cut at
Walter's. The capitalists who are carrying
on these businesses are both desirous of getting
a coin like that mentioned.

Last week I was heating potassium ferro-cyanide,
and chanced to go out to exchange smiles with a
friend during the process. When I returned the compound had partially decomposed. Can you suggest
an automatic method ? Also am having trouble with
my family. Papa refuses to advance my next December allowance. What shall I do ?—Junior.

Give the ferro-cyanide to the cook to heat
for you in the frying pan. This will also prevent further trouble from your people. It is
H. R. V.
killing two birds with one stone.

Manager P. Wroth, Jr., of the track team
has resigned, and assistant manager Aubrey
Pearre is now acting in that capacity.
Captain Tyler of the Lacrosse team has had
his men out several times during the past
week for practice at Druid Hill Park. As yet
little attempt has been made to pick the team
which will represent Hopkins during the coming season.
AS JP

The candidates for the Lacrosse team were
given a chalk talk on Saturday afternoon by
Capt. Tyler, Coaches Maddren and Abercrombie, and Messrs.Bernheim and Schmeisser.
With the aid of a black board and a set of
chess men, the system of play was clearly
outlined, and various points of the game
clearly demonstrated. Billy Maddren concluded the talk by giving the men some good
advice on the discipline of a team on the field—
the importance of obeying the captain implicitly, of avoiding the "spread out" style of
play, and of dependance on stick work rather
than running.
St. John's College was not represented at
the recent indoor athletic meet at Georgetown.
The reason assigned by the management was
the lack of necessary facilities to develop this
branch of sport.
www
At the annual meeting of the Intercollegiate
Athletic Association, held in New York
February 23d. Johns Hopkins University
was reinstated in the Association. Our expulsion was due to the fact that for three
years (1897, 1898, 1899) we were unable
through lack of proper management and
facilities to hold track and field meets. Several
important amendments relative to the schoolastic standing of college athletes were made to
the by-laws of the Association.

THE NEWS-LETTER.
THE GEORGETOWN MEET.
CHEERED on by a small band of enthusiastic "rooters," the Hopkins boys at the
annual indoor meet of the Georgetown University, were able to carry off all the places in
the shot put, first and second in the 220 yard
dash, third in the high jump, third in the 440;
and the relay team won in handy fashion from
the Washington Y. M. C. A.
Watson, Tootle, Whitman, and Atkinson
qualified for the semi-finals in the 50 yard
dash, but none of them were able to get into
the finals. The event was won by the famous
W. J. Holland, of Georgetown, in 5.01.
Tootle surprised himself and every one else
by finishing first in the 220 dash. In the first
heat, Tootle, with a handicap of 20 yards, was
first with Atkinson, who also had 20 yards, a
dangerous second. The final heat was only a
repetition of the first. Time, 24 seconds.
Whitman, England, Hoffman, and Riggs
were the men scheduled for the relay team, and
ran in the order named. It was rumored that
the Y. M. C. A. men were offering 2 to i on
their team, but unfortunately for some of the
sanguine and enthusiastic Hopkins"rooters"
the report could not be verified. No relay
race is decided until the finish is reached, but
it was soon seen that, barring accidents, the
Hopkins fellows would win with a safe
margin. Riggs crossed the line a winner with
plenty of daylight between himself and the
Y. M. C. A. contestant.
Thatcher, with 38 yards, and Riggs, with
30 yards, were the only J. H. U. men who
toed the mark for the 440 yard race.
Thatcher ran well up for a while, but the pace
was too hot, and he was compelled to fall back.
By a magnificent spurt that brought him from
a place far in the rear, Riggs managed to
capture third place. J. Gilden, 28 yards, won
the race, with J. H. O'Brien, 28 yards, second.
Both were Georgetown men. Time, 56
minutes flat.
In the high jump I. K. Baxter, unattached
(scratch), won the event by jumping 6 feet,
2 inches. Second was S. S. Jones, of New
York University. Third honors were divided

9

betweenl George B. Scholl, of J. H. U. (5
inches),and Rob ert Garret (5 inches).
The shot put earned for our weight men an
enviable reputation. The event was won by
G. B. Scholl, 8 feet, whose actual put was 33
feet, 8 inches; second, Harvey B. Stone, 8
'feet, actual put 33 feet, 554 inches; third,
H. S. Whitman, 7 feet, actual put 33 feet,
inch.
These were the only events in which Hopkins was entered. Among other features on
the program which attracted general interest
were the 50 yard special dash, the mile run,
the 2 mile run, the special relay races, and
Wefer's exhibition 220.
The special dash brought together some of
the best men in the country. As was expected,
Duffy carried off the honors. He ran the fifty
yards in five seconds flat. This lowers the
record for Convention Hall.
With 25 yards handicap, Stuart, of University of Pennsylvania, was able to beat Dick
Grant, (scratch) of Harvard, in the mile run.
Bernard Wefers ran an exhibition 220 yards in
pace. Time 22.4 seconds.
The 2 mile run was a nip-and-tuck
fight between the Grant brothers. The last
quarter was run at quarter-dash speed. Alex.
Grant was able to finish a few strides ahead of
his brother. Time 10.31.
Cornell defeated Columbia in a hotly con_
tested relay race by about four yards.
The Georgetown University defeated the
University of Pennsylvania in one of the most
exciting relay races of the evening.
The interscholastic 50 yard dash was won
by Chester Cloud, of Marston's Preparatory
School.
A relay race betwen four prep. schools, Marston's, Boy's Latin School, Friends' Select
School, of Washington, and the Emerson
Institute, of Washington, was won by the
team from the Boy's Latin School, with the
team of the Friends' School a close second.
The 88o yard handicap, interscholastic, was
won by Crook, of Marston's.

taught our boys for twenty-five years
WE'VE
The paths that lead to life;
We've loved and cherished their hopes and fears
Their work and laughter, play and tears
Till our name to them a world endears
Where they'll glorify the strife—
But now from this hearty, hustling town
We ask for a million dollars down.
We've braved the dust of the madding street
And the hurly burly throng
Where the wheels of business stop our feet
As we seek a spot for a mind's retreat
Or we falter amid the garish heat
While we forward press along
To our storied halls through the turbid town,
Waiting those million dollars down.
The trees are broad in the Homewood lanes
And the prospect bountiful
There's life afield for our palsied brains
Dame Nature is there to heal our pains
Sound bodies and minds and eternal gains
For hearts that are throbbing full
We reach for these from the strenuous town—
A world for a million dollars down!
Back to Nature! As Greeks of old
To the the fruitful templed bills!
The fountains of life the fields enfold
TiE there we'll find the philosopher's gold
The door of the Future aside is rolled
And it closes on old ills
The promised land is beyond the town—
Life for a million dollars down!
Life for ourselves and the town we serve
Life for the world of thought.
Life, as never an inch we swerve
Straining each head and heart and nerve
Drawing our stores from a deep reserve
For the striving souls we've sought
To show a heaven beyond the town—
True! for a million dollars down !
Each dollar will make a better soul,
Each soul a better world;
For we've filled the world from the pole to pole
With the world of knowledge we now control
And wherever humanity's waves may roll,
Our standard is high unfurled
In harbors and homes of State and Town
Wherever men hunt for the dollars down.
There are banks—aye! the banks of the woodland
There are bonds that bind the heart [brooks!
In the haunts of learning where each man looks
For his fellow-man in his fellow books
And builds a Life Way in hidden nooks
Where Science englories Art,
Come from the banks and bonds of town
And give us a realm for a new renown
By plunking that glorious million down.
J. Mee. T. '96.

OUR TWENTY-FIFTH ANNIVERSARY. student body; frequent interruptions and
several reasons the Commemoration Day
FOR
Celebration in McCoy Hall, on February
was the grandest and most impressive of
many years past. It not only marked the
twenty-fifth birth-day of the University, but
witnessed, with regrets, the resignation of the
first and only president of the institution.
The attention of the public, which has been
recently turned upon Johns Hopkins on account of our newly acquired possessions, also
contributed to gather the illustrious assemblage which makes the day a memorable one.
The one thing, however, which remained to
distinguish the day in the annals of the University, and to mark the beginning of a new
epoch of unprecedented success, was wanting.
Students, faculty, and friends alike waited with
hopeful expectation to hear the announcements
from "Uncle Dan," but the all important one,
the one which all had 'anxiously awaited,
brought only disappointment. Let us all,
like Uncle Dan, "have faith in the people,
faith in human nature."
Another subject for surmise among the
audience was the probable successor of President Gilman. One or two newspapers have
insinuated that Dr. David J. Hill, the orator
of the day, may be the man, but thus far,
nothing definite has been learned. The ovation given Dr. Hill at the conclusion of his
speech, by friends and students alike, plainly
attests the favorable impression which he
made. His address was both eloquent and
scholarly, and his personality plainly indicates
those qualities which always command respect.
The yelling in one or two instances was very
ill-timed. "There is a time for all things,"
and upon these occasions extraordinary care
should be taken in the control of such demonstrations. Appropriate yells at seasonable
moments not only lend interest to the programme, but impress the audience very favorably with the college spirit and unity of the
22,

ragged yelling at untimely moments, however,
become extremely annoying, and brand the
students as rowdies, having very indistinct
ideas of propriety. One or two outbreaks of
this nature were visible on Commemoration
Day, and in the future pains should be taken
to eliminate such detrimental proceedings.
An assemblage of well-known statesmen and
scholars filled the stage. Besides our able
faculty were a number of distinguished guests,
including Senor Aspirez, the Mexican ambassador; Mr. Torey, of the Mexican embassy;
Count and Countess Lichtervelde, the minister
from Switzerland, and many others, among
them our kind benefactors, Mr. William Wyman and Mr. William S. Keyser.
Following the chant "Benedictus," President Gilman introduced Dr. Hill, who gave a
highly entertaining address on "The Influence
of Universities upon National Life."
The degree of Doctor of Philosophy was
conferred upon Messrs. George Ernest Barnett,
Benjamin Palmer Caldwell, Arthur Henry
Ewing and Norman Everett Gilbert.
President Gilman announced his resignation
in a simple, brief address, and proceeded to
the announcements. In a few words the expectant audience was informed that the $1,000,000 had not yet made its appearance, and that
no means for securing it had yet been devised.
No little pleasure was expressed by the
friends of Dr. Paul Haupt at the honor conferred upon him by Emperor William. At
the conclusion of the exercises President and
Mrs. Gilman entertained Dr. Hill and the
guests from Washington in the Donovan Room.
During the day Dr. Gilman was the recipient of the following telegrams from the various

THE ALUMNI BANQUET.
IT felt quite like old times to meet the fellows
again, some of whom you had not seenfor a
year, some for two years, and sonic not since
you left the University. The hundred or more
of us who met at the Rennert the evening of
Commemoration Day did most heartily celebrate the twenty-fifth birthday of our Alma
Mater, and our reunion.
We were very fortunate to have with us that
evening Mr. Wyman,through whose generosity
Greater Johns Hopkins becomes a probability,
and although Messrs Keyser, and Jencks and
the other gentlemen who joined them in their
gift to us were not present, they were not
forgotten.
Mr. Geo. Dobbin Penniman was toastmaster,
and seated on either side of him at the head

table were the speakers of the evening, President Oilman, Messrs John K. Cowen, Wm.
H. Buckter, and Dr. James C. Mackenzie, of
Tome Institute, and Mr. J. R. Brackett, the
newly elected President of the Alumni Association.
Dr. Gilman was given quite an ovation of
cheers and applause when he entered the room,
and but for his especial request should like to
tell you all he said, but I can only hint that he
told us how he captured Drs. Gildersleeve,
Sylvester, and Rowland twenty-five years ago.
Dr. Gilman was followed by Mr. Wyman
who spoke a few words of thanks for the
hearty and prolonged applause which greeted
him. Then came Mr. Cowen who told us
what a good railroad man a college man made,
and also said, in reference to the proposed new
ballot, that he recommended its being printed
in Sanskrit so that only Dr. Haupt and a few
others as deeply versed in original and research
work might.have the honor of voting intelligently.
Dr. Mackenzie then gave us an interesting
account of the Prep. Schools which he called
the "Kitchens of the Universities."
The last speaker was Mr. Buckter who spoke
on the educated man, what he had done in the
past, and what was before him for the future.
In the intervals between toasts a quartette
from the Glee Club, and four members of .the
Banjo Club entertained us with music, and we
all sang some of the old songs we used to sing
when we were freshmen.
The banquet closed with Auld Sang Sync,
which was sung standing, and we all left to
meet again next year.
J. F. V. '98.

THE PUBLIC DEBATE.

JUNIOR BANQUET.

IT has been definitely decided that the Interclass Debate between Juniors and Seniors,
and the Freshman contest in public ipeaking,
will be held this year on Thursday, March
21st, at 8 p. in., in McCoy Hall. These contests always bring out interest in student
affairs by the public of Baltimore, and the
hall is generally filled to overflowing. This
year the debate, and the Freshman contest are
expected to be very interesting and exciting,
as the men of all three classes are working
hard. The side winning the debate receives
the Adams Trophy, which, despite the resignation of Prof. Adams, has again been offered,
and each member of the winning team is
recompensed by books also given by Dr.
Adams. The Lee Trophy is the reward to
the best Freshman Speaker.
The Senior team is hard at work with about
twelve candidates for the nine positions. The
men trying for the speakers' positions are :—
Bird, Boyer, Swindell, Tyler, Whitman, Riggins, Bandel, secretary, and Machen, chairman.
The members of the Junior team have also
been pushing along, and are making very
satisfactory progress. The first and second
speakers will be chosen shortly, and several
men have already begun training. Naughty
two is generally supporting the team, whose
meetings are weJ1 attended. The places will
probably be distributed among the following
men :—Markell, secretary, Diggs, Campbell,
Strouse, Stone, chairman, Neer, Pels, Putts,
Guggenheimer, Wohnan, Wroth. The question to be debated is Resolved, "That the
United States should build, own, operate and
control an inter-oceanic canal, by way of
Nicaragua." The Juniors have the affirmative,
and the Seniors the negative. The question
is a good one for debate, and a warm contest
may be expected.
'Four Freshmen will speak in the contest for
public speaking. Many men started out, but
at the time of going to press it was stated
that the speakers would probably be chosen
from the following :—Addison, Dochez, Blum,
Meeks, Tootle, Plaggemeyer, Zimmerman.

Junior Class held its annual banquet
THE
at the Mt. Vernon Hotel, on Thursday
evening, February twenty-first. The, affair
from start to finish was a success and everyone
enjoyed himself to his utmost. The presence
of Messrs Sneeringer and White was a sure
guarantee that there would be little time spent
in silent meditation, and the evening was one
grand opera. All the songs from the most
recent to those of "by gone days'' were sung,
and it was evident that there were other musical stars besides those on the Glee Club.
The menu and toast cards were tastefully
gotten up, and the committee on arrangements
Messrs.Beasley,Moore and Koppleman deserve
to be congratulated. The committee on toasts
was composed of Messrs Wroth, Sneeringer
and Myers. liben C. Hill was toastmaster,
and called upon the following men for toasts.
Robert E. Moore, "Old Toni Hopkins'';
Horace Gillespie, "Our Missing Ribs'' Lyman
C. Murphy, "Our Newly Acquired Possessions" ; Robert T. Crane, "Our Royal Selves";
W.J. Sneeringer, Jr., "Harmony In Uproar";
C. A. Myers,"Our Fincounter with the Freshman"; J. G. Campbell, "The Rough House
of Representatives'' -and Harvey B. Stone,
"Athletics." After the toasts, songs were
sung and stories were told till just before the
banquet broke up when everybody gathered
at one end of the hall and ended the evening
with "Rah! for the Black and Blue!" and
some rousing "Hullabaloo's."
It seems a pity that more of these banquets
could not be held throughout the year, for it is
the only chance that the men in the class have
to come together and know each other better.
Possibly later in the year, some "palm garden"
feeds can be held which will be just as jolly
and cost a great deal less.

With the exception of the "Hullabaloo,"
the NEWS-LETTER is the sole undergraduate
publication of the Johns Hopkins, and consequently occupies a unique position among
the college papers. Elsewhere it is usually
customary for a college paper to devote itself
exclusively to one particular line of work,—
humorous, literary, athletic, or to matters of
local interest, as the case may be, while we are
forced to cover the entire sphere. Hence, it
is our aim, first, to disseminate University
news, and second to publish such articles as
may be of interest to the reader. It is the
intention of the present board of editors to pursue this policy, and to aid us in this endeavor
we earnestly solicit the co-operation of every
Hopkins man, and particularly the undergraduates. Items of University interest, and helpful hints and suggestions would benefit us
materially. Above all, the NEWS-LETTER is.
conducted by the students, for the students.

our last issue a change has taken
SINCE
place in the editorial staff of the NEws-

LETTER, and a new editor-in-chief, not without reluctance, assumes the arduous duties
connected with that office. Before proceeding
further it is eminently befitting to congratulate
the retiring editor upon the excellent manner
in which the paper has been conducted during
his incumbency in office. Mr. Norman Boyer
has been connected with the NEWS-LETTER
since his Freshman year, and has occupied
successively the positions of assistant athletic
editor, news editor, associate editor, and editor-in-chief. During the last-named period
Mr. Boyer's aim has been to exemplify in these
columns the province of the college paper,
namely, to publish that kind of news which
directly interests the student. In pursuing
this aim he has advanced the standard of the
paper, and, largely owing to his efforts, it now
occupies a much more vital position among
Hopkins students than it was possible for it to
hold a few years ago. The endeavor of the
the paper is to come in close contact with every
student of the University.

A vacancy now exists on the editorial staff
of the NEWS-LETTER, and an opportunity is
thereby afforded for a display of literary ability
among the aspiring members of the Freshman
Class. A position upon the NEWS-LETTER
gives a man good, practical experience in literary training, which will prove valuable to
him in after years, and we strongly urge those
who are desirous of obtaining this position to
hand in, as soon as possible, specimens of their
writing, in the form of accounts of athletic
events, or matters of University interest. The
vacancy will probably be filled before the next
issue of this paper, so the sooner the competitive articles are turned in the better.

THE NEWS-LETTER.
We wonder if the Board of Trustees knew
as much about this as does our smart New
England friend.
This logical conclusion rests upon the
statement made by President Gilman in the
course of the Commemoration Day exercises,
that next October a formal celebration of the
twenty-fifth anniversary of the beginning of
academic work is to be held, at which time
the retired President is expected to make a
few remarks, and the incoming executive will
make his inaugural address. This, says the
Massachusetts editor, does not look as if the
trustees were still groping in the dark.
Dr. David Jayne Hill, who delivered the
Commemoration Day address, would make an
admirable president, having already served in
that capacity at both Bucknell and Rochester
Universities. He is a man of culture and
learning, and is known extensively as an
author of works on finance, rhetoric, biography
and psychology.

for when the matter is sifted, it comes down to
the question of whether or not we wish to promote Hopkins athletics. Every one realizes
the inestimable service Physical Director Mackdermott rendered us by procuring, for a nominal sum, a five-year lease on the new American
League grounds; but while we have secured
the grounds, it requires a certain amount of
capital to make the necessary improvements,
and as the alumni are interested in the Homewood site, the money for our present needs
must come from the student body. The
"Homewood" athletic field will be a great
boon to us, when we get it, but in the meantime it is necessary to carry on athletics,
and while future Hopkins classes may enjoy
"Homewood," the present ones will use
American League Park.

PATIENCE.

LAST we have a dramatic club! This
ATannouncement
should bring joy into the
camp of Hopkins, and arouse the enthusiasm
of the mighty masses ready to support worthy
enterprises. The club has not only been organized, but a play has been chosen, the cast
selected, the chorus drilled, and the ballet
formed. Everything started smoothly, and it
is hoped that the impetus given to this undertaking by the student body will urge the organization to complete success this year and a permanent position among Hopkins institutions
in future decades. J. Alan Haughton, 1903,
conceived the idea, and he, with the men asked
to co-operate, pressed matters to a head with
admirable expediency, so that now it can be
announced that the opera, "Patience," by Gilbert and Sullivan, will be rendered by the
Hopkins "Puff and Patch Club," probably
during the last week in April.
Why should not Hopkins have a dramatic
society? Some years ago "The Mask and Wig
Club," of the University of Pennsylvania,
toured the country for two seasons with their
"Mr. and Mrs. Cleopatra," and "Miss Columbia," and were eminently successful. In 1893
or 1894 the "Triangle Club," of Princeton,
put forth "Julius Csar," a clever musical
burlesque; Chicago, in the spring of 1899, gave
"The Deceitful Dean," and now the students
of Columbia are producing at the Carnegie
Lyceum, in New York, "Princess Proud,"
written and composed entirely by the college
men. Hopkins ought to be able tc do every
bit as much in this line as the larger universities, and should exert every effort to produce
a successful play. The advantages to be derived from a dramatic club have already been
pointed out in these columns.
Almost everybody admits that the idea is
good if it can be worked out; and to show that
it is possible the "Puff and Patch Club" has
been started here in hopes that the students
will evince sufficient interest to earnestly take
hold of the matter, now in a tangible form.
The reasons why "Patience" has been selected
to air our histrionic abilities are obvious.
Whereas other good operas have been given

since 1881; the choruses are, with two or three
exceptions, sung in unison, thereby reducing

But the primary cause of the choice lies in the
fact that most of the solos are good, all are
"catchy," and the book ,witty as it is now, with
a little modernizing can be made screamingly

MANDOLIN CLUB.

Mandolin Club took part in an enterTHE
tainment given at the Girls' Latin School
last Thursday night. The Club was on the
programme to appear but twice, so that when
the last piece was played, there was nothing
else to do except to remain and wait for any
forthcoming refreshments, or to adjourn to the
street and there give the members of the Glee
Club a chance to air their voices.
Accordingly all the instruments were gathered together, and the crowd started down
Saint Paul Street singing "Bring the Wagon
Home, John." But on the way, some one,
evidently well acquainted with the situation of
the Woman's College Dormitories, suggested
that the men serenade the College girls. So
all turned back and started for the nearest
Home.
Here a number of popular songs and "Hullabaloos" were given, accompanied with sub-

dued applause from the upper windows. Then
things were thrown. Apples seemed to be the
greatest drug on the market, for during the
serenade many of these appeared. The men
at first were undecided how to take these
tokens, not knowing whether they were thrown
from love of the singing and the men, or from
a desire to discourage the serenaders. However, being a trifle vain, they decided it was
more complimentary than otherwise, for surely
College girls never waste apples when other
things would serve just as well as missiles.
So the concert continued till all the dormitories
had been visited and the night watchman not
appreciating the music (?) had brought a
policeman to his assistance. Then having no
permit to "give a performance on the street''
the crowd disbanded.
w 941r

MR. FREDERICK HARRISON.
who will lecture here shortly,
MR.is Harrison,
of interest to students from two quite
distinct points of view. Besides holding high
rank as a critic and a master of English prose,
he is an important figure in the history of philosophic thought during the past half century.
A follower of Auguste Comte, whom he
expressly recognizes as his master, he many
years ago came into prominence as the prophet
of Positivism in England. While making
little if any addition to the doctrine itself, he
gave to its propaganda as a cult the powerful
aid of his literary ability. The "Religion of
Humanity'' had in him its ablest advocate.
His position with regard to Positivism was
closely akin to that held by Mr. Huxley toward the doctrine of evolution. They were
the defenders and expounders of their respective causes. To them the popular ear was
open. In the ferment attending the birth of
the theory of evolution, there was necessarily
much re-examination of philosophy, and it was
at this time that Mr. Harrison came to be
regarded as the especial champion of the Positivist cause in England. In recent years his
work has been along more purely literary lines,
although it is not improbable his philosophy
has had much to do with giving his work in
part a historical direction. To this we owe
his excellent study of "Oliver Cromwell''
and his suggestive book on the "Meaning of
History."

Last week I was heating potassium ferro-cyanide,
and chanced to go out to exchange smiles with a
friend during the process. When I returned the compound had partially decomposed. Can you suggest
an automatic method ? Also am having trouble with
my family. Papa refuses to advance my next December allowance. What shall I do ?—Junior.

Give the ferro-cyanide to the cook to heat
for you in the frying pan. This will also prevent further trouble from your people. It is
H. R. V.
killing two birds with one stone.

The candidates for the Lacrosse team were
given a chalk talk on Saturday afternoon by
Capt. Tyler, Coaches Maddren and Abercrombie, and Messrs.Bernheim and Schmeisser.
With the aid of a black board and a set of
chess men, the system of play was clearly
outlined, and various points of the game
clearly demonstrated. Billy Maddren concluded the talk by giving the men some good
advice on the discipline of a team on the field—
the importance of obeying the captain implicitly, of avoiding the "spread out" style of
play, and of dependance on stick work rather
than running.

the lack of necessary facilities to develop this
branch of sport.

THE NEWS-LETTER.
THE GEORGETOWN MEET.
CHEERED on by a small band of enthusiastic "rooters," the Hopkins boys at the
annual indoor meet of the Georgetown University, were able to carry off all the places in
the shot put, first and second in the 220 yard
dash, third in the high jump, third in the 440;
and the relay team won in handy fashion from
the Washington Y. M. C. A.
Watson, Tootle, Whitman, and Atkinson
qualified for the semi-finals in the 50 yard
dash, but none of them were able to get into
the finals. The event was won by the famous
W. J. Holland, of Georgetown, in 5.01.
Tootle surprised himself and every one else
by finishing first in the 220 dash. In the first
heat, Tootle, with a handicap of 20 yards, was
first with Atkinson, who also had 20 yards, a
dangerous second. The final heat was only a
repetition of the first. Time, 24 seconds.
Whitman, England, Hoffman, and Riggs
were the men scheduled for the relay team, and
ran in the order named. It was rumored that
the Y. M. C. A. men were offering 2 to i on
their team, but unfortunately for some of the
sanguine and enthusiastic Hopkins"rooters"
the report could not be verified. No relay
race is decided until the finish is reached, but
it was soon seen that, barring accidents, the
Hopkins fellows would win with a safe
margin. Riggs crossed the line a winner with
plenty of daylight between himself and the
Y. M. C. A. contestant.
Thatcher, with 38 yards, and Riggs, with
30 yards, were the only J. H. U. men who
toed the mark for the 440 yard race.
Thatcher ran well up for a while, but the pace
was too hot, and he was compelled to fall back.
By a magnificent spurt that brought him from
a place far in the rear, Riggs managed to
capture third place. J. Gilden, 28 yards, won
the race, with J. H. O'Brien, 28 yards, second.
Both were Georgetown men. Time, 56
minutes flat.
In the high jump I. K. Baxter, unattached
(scratch), won the event by jumping 6 feet,
2 inches. Second was S. S. Jones, of New
York University. Third honors were divided

9

betweenl George B. Scholl, of J. H. U. (5
inches),and Rob ert Garret (5 inches).
The shot put earned for our weight men an
enviable reputation. The event was won by
G. B. Scholl, 8 feet, whose actual put was 33
feet, 8 inches; second, Harvey B. Stone, 8
'feet, actual put 33 feet, 554 inches; third,
H. S. Whitman, 7 feet, actual put 33 feet,
inch.
These were the only events in which Hopkins was entered. Among other features on
the program which attracted general interest
were the 50 yard special dash, the mile run,
the 2 mile run, the special relay races, and
Wefer's exhibition 220.
The special dash brought together some of
the best men in the country. As was expected,
Duffy carried off the honors. He ran the fifty
yards in five seconds flat. This lowers the
record for Convention Hall.
With 25 yards handicap, Stuart, of University of Pennsylvania, was able to beat Dick
Grant, (scratch) of Harvard, in the mile run.
Bernard Wefers ran an exhibition 220 yards in
pace. Time 22.4 seconds.
The 2 mile run was a nip-and-tuck
fight between the Grant brothers. The last
quarter was run at quarter-dash speed. Alex.
Grant was able to finish a few strides ahead of
his brother. Time 10.31.
Cornell defeated Columbia in a hotly con_
tested relay race by about four yards.
The Georgetown University defeated the
University of Pennsylvania in one of the most
exciting relay races of the evening.
The interscholastic 50 yard dash was won
by Chester Cloud, of Marston's Preparatory
School.
A relay race betwen four prep. schools, Marston's, Boy's Latin School, Friends' Select
School, of Washington, and the Emerson
Institute, of Washington, was won by the
team from the Boy's Latin School, with the
team of the Friends' School a close second.
The 88o yard handicap, interscholastic, was
won by Crook, of Marston's.

taught our boys for twenty-five years
WE'VE
The paths that lead to life;
We've loved and cherished their hopes and fears
Their work and laughter, play and tears
Till our name to them a world endears
Where they'll glorify the strife—
But now from this hearty, hustling town
We ask for a million dollars down.
We've braved the dust of the madding street
And the hurly burly throng
Where the wheels of business stop our feet
As we seek a spot for a mind's retreat
Or we falter amid the garish heat
While we forward press along
To our storied halls through the turbid town,
Waiting those million dollars down.
The trees are broad in the Homewood lanes
And the prospect bountiful
There's life afield for our palsied brains
Dame Nature is there to heal our pains
Sound bodies and minds and eternal gains
For hearts that are throbbing full
We reach for these from the strenuous town—
A world for a million dollars down!
Back to Nature! As Greeks of old
To the the fruitful templed bills!
The fountains of life the fields enfold
TiE there we'll find the philosopher's gold
The door of the Future aside is rolled
And it closes on old ills
The promised land is beyond the town—
Life for a million dollars down!
Life for ourselves and the town we serve
Life for the world of thought.
Life, as never an inch we swerve
Straining each head and heart and nerve
Drawing our stores from a deep reserve
For the striving souls we've sought
To show a heaven beyond the town—
True! for a million dollars down !
Each dollar will make a better soul,
Each soul a better world;
For we've filled the world from the pole to pole
With the world of knowledge we now control
And wherever humanity's waves may roll,
Our standard is high unfurled
In harbors and homes of State and Town
Wherever men hunt for the dollars down.
There are banks—aye! the banks of the woodland
There are bonds that bind the heart [brooks!
In the haunts of learning where each man looks
For his fellow-man in his fellow books
And builds a Life Way in hidden nooks
Where Science englories Art,
Come from the banks and bonds of town
And give us a realm for a new renown
By plunking that glorious million down.
J. Mee. T. '96.
